entry.title: Experience Required?
entry.summary: Where do you get initial communication opportunities? Internships _ paid and unpaid. Intern by project or volunteer for limited time commitments.
entry.content:
Switching careers or getting started in communications can be tough when you don’t have experience in the field.

How do you get that “foot in the door”? Take every opportunity to stretch yourself and apply new skills – especially social media monitoring, web writing/blogging, and blogger profile research. Where do you get these opportunities? Unpaid internships with not-for-profits and volunteering with IABC. Yes, really – almost all industry veterans at one time did unpaid internships. My internship was for Columbus Clean Community, giving presentations on recycling. I had to wear a dinosaur costume on certain occasions as a mascot .

If you have an opportunity to write tweets and facebook posts to promote events for a nonprofit – DO IT!  Gaining experience in the field is a must.

entry.title: IABC
entry.summary: IABC is a professional group for communicators
entry.content:
The International Association of Business Communicators (IABC) is an important professional group for communicators.  The majority of their members have at least 10 years experience.

Join and have access to special internship and job listings, events, publications and tools for communication planning, and networking . Student yearly membership are $65 – special preview and joining deals in September!

entry.title: Delivering the Goods
entry.summary: Blogs, tweets, FaceBook posts, e-memos, fliers, and communication audits are all types of communication deliverables. Basically, it's what you "deliver" to the client.
entry.content:
Communications professionals need to “deliver the goods” – creating different types of communication products (i.e., deliverables). 

What’s a “deliverable”?  Blogs, tweets, FaceBook posts, e-memos, fliers, and communication audits  are all types of communication deliverables.  Basically, it’s what you “deliver” to the client. 

 

That includes the “look” as well as the content, so you write the content and use fonts, white space, color, and graphics to make it appealing for the audience. 

Sound cool? It IS — Communications is a dynamic field to work in where you are doing something different every day.

entry.title: Why Communications?
entry.summary: Communication skills are critical to career survival in the complex organizations of the 21st century and the Communications major offers a pragmatic mix of core communication courses, social science courses, and business courses.
